texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: I spoke with a customer last week who was curious about enabling encrypted partitions on a DAS connected to their server.  I wasn't entirely sure if it was possible in RHEL 5 since I couldn't remember if it was available in Fedora 6.  According to  Red Hat's release notes , it is possible.  Here's an excerpt from their release notes:
texts.text: I spoke with a customer last week who was curious about enabling encrypted partitions on a DAS connected to their server.  I wasn't entirely sure if it was possible in RHEL 5 since I couldn't remember if it was available in Fedora 6.  According to  Red Hat's release notes , it is possible.  Here's an excerpt from their release notes:

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Encrypted Swap Partitions and Non-root File Systems
texts.text: Encrypted Swap Partitions and Non-root File Systems

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Red Hat Enterprise Linux 5 now provides basic support for encrypted swap partitions and non-root file systems. To use these features, add the appropriate entries to /etc/crypttab and reference the created devices in /etc/fstab.
texts.text: Red Hat Enterprise Linux 5 now provides basic support for encrypted swap partitions and non-root file systems. To use these features, add the appropriate entries to /etc/crypttab and reference the created devices in /etc/fstab.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Below is a sample /etc/crypttab entry:
texts.text: Below is a sample /etc/crypttab entry:

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: my_swap /dev/hdb1 /dev/urandom swap,cipher=aes-cbc-essiv:sha256
texts.text: my_swap /dev/hdb1 /dev/urandom swap,cipher=aes-cbc-essiv:sha256

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: This creates the encrypted block device /dev/mapper/my_swap, which can be referenced in /etc/fstab.
texts.text: This creates the encrypted block device /dev/mapper/my_swap, which can be referenced in /etc/fstab.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Below is a sample /etc/crypttab entry for a file system volume:
texts.text: Below is a sample /etc/crypttab entry for a file system volume:

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: my volume /dev/hda5 /etc/volume key cipher=aes-cbc-essiv:sha256
texts.text: my volume /dev/hda5 /etc/volume key cipher=aes-cbc-essiv:sha256

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: The /etc/volume_key file contains a plaintext encryption key. You can also specify none as the key file name; this configures the system to ask for the encryption key during boot instead.
texts.text: The /etc/volume_key file contains a plaintext encryption key. You can also specify none as the key file name; this configures the system to ask for the encryption key during boot instead.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: It is recommended to use LUKS (Linux Unified Key Setup) for setting up file system volumes. To do this, follow these steps:
texts.text: It is recommended to use LUKS (Linux Unified Key Setup) for setting up file system volumes. To do this, follow these steps:

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Create the encrypted volume using cryptsetup luksFormat.
texts.text: Create the encrypted volume using cryptsetup luksFormat.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Add the necessary entry to /etc/crypttab.
texts.text: Add the necessary entry to /etc/crypttab.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Set up the volume manually using cryptsetup luksOpen (or reboot).
texts.text: Set up the volume manually using cryptsetup luksOpen (or reboot).

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Create a file system on the encrypted volume.
texts.text: Create a file system on the encrypted volume.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Add the necessary entry to /etc/fstab.
texts.text: Add the necessary entry to /etc/fstab.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: After scouring the Red Hat Enterprise Linux manuals and knowledge base, I couldn't find specific instructions to set it up. However, there was an  article in the Red Hat Magazine  that may help.
